content.title: Trigeminal Neuralgia
content.summary: Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is a facial pain disorder characterized by sudden, brief, unilateral, electric shock-like paroxysms in the distribution of one or more trigeminal nerve branches, typically triggered by innocuous stimuli. Carbamazepine is first-line treatment, with microvascular decompression for refractory cases.
key_points: Classic TN: sudden, severe, lancinating pain lasting seconds to 2 minutes
V2 (maxillary) and V3 (mandibular) most commonly affected
Triggered by light touch, chewing, talking, cold wind
Carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine is first-line treatment
MRI with dedicated neurovascular sequences to exclude secondary causes
Microvascular decompression for medically refractory cases
content.statement: Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by recurrent paroxysms of unilateral facial pain in the trigeminal distribution, typically triggered by innocuous stimuli, caused by neurovascular compression or secondary pathology, and treated with anticonvulsants or surgical decompression.

explanation.intuition: Imagine the trigeminal nerve as a frayed electrical wire. When something touches the frayed area - even a gentle breeze or brushing teeth - it short-circuits and sends searing pain signals. That's why patients describe 'electric shocks' triggered by harmless activities.
explanation.key_insight: The distinction between classic (Type 1) and Type 2 TN is clinically important: Type 1 has discrete attacks with pain-free intervals; Type 2 has constant background pain with superimposed paroxysms. This affects treatment selection and prognosis.
explanation.technical_details: Neurovascular compression, typically by the superior cerebellar artery at the root entry zone, causes focal demyelination. This creates ephaptic transmission (cross-talk) between fibers, explaining why light touch (Aβ fibers) triggers pain (Aδ/C fiber activation). MRI with FIESTA/CISS sequences visualizes the offending vessel.

definitions_glossary.trigeminal_neuralgia: Facial pain disorder with lancinating paroxysms in trigeminal distribution
definitions_glossary.paroxysmal_pain: Sudden, brief attacks of pain lasting seconds to minutes
definitions_glossary.trigger_zone: Facial area where stimulation provokes pain attack
definitions_glossary.refractory_period: Brief period after attack when new attack cannot be triggered
definitions_glossary.V2_maxillary: Second trigeminal division (cheek, upper lip, upper teeth)
definitions_glossary.V3_mandibular: Third trigeminal division (lower face, jaw, lower teeth)
definitions_glossary.neurovascular_compression: Vascular loop compressing nerve root; most common cause of classic TN
definitions_glossary.microvascular_decompression: MVD; surgery to separate vessel from nerve
definitions_glossary.secondary_TN: TN caused by MS, tumor, or other structural lesion
definitions_glossary.ephaptic_transmission: Abnormal cross-talk between nerve fibers due to demyelination

pathophysiology.mechanism: Focal demyelination at trigeminal root entry zone causing abnormal nerve firing

classic_TN.mechanism: Pulsatile compression causes focal demyelination → ephaptic transmission

ICHD3_criteria.A: At least 3 attacks of unilateral facial pain
ICHD3_criteria.B: In one or more trigeminal divisions, no radiation beyond
ICHD3_criteria.C: At least 3 of: (1) paroxysmal, seconds to 2 min; (2) severe intensity; (3) electric shock-like/shooting/stabbing/sharp
ICHD3_criteria.D: Triggered by innocuous stimuli to the affected side
ICHD3_criteria.E: Not better accounted for by another diagnosis

classic_TN.type_2: Constant background pain with superimposed paroxysms

subtypes.secondary_TN: TN caused by identifiable underlying disease (MS, tumor)
subtypes.idiopathic_TN: No neurovascular compression or secondary cause identified

clinical_features: Triggered by light touch, chewing, talking, cold
Neurological exam usually NORMAL in classic TN

MRI_brain.standard: Rule out secondary causes (tumor, MS plaques)
MRI_brain.neurovascular_protocol: FIESTA/CISS sequences to identify vascular compression

required_workup.trigeminal_reflexes: If sensory loss present; abnormal in secondary TN

differential_diagnosis: Dental pain (continuous, throbbing, related to teeth)
TMJ disorder (pain with jaw movement, clicking)
Postherpetic neuralgia (history of shingles, constant pain)

carbamazepine.monitoring: CBC, LFTs, sodium; HLA-B*1502 in Asian patients (SJS risk)

percutaneous_rhizotomy.indication: Poor surgical candidate, elderly, prefer lower-risk procedure

treatment_of_secondary_TN: Treat underlying cause (MS disease-modifying therapy, tumor resection)

definition.@value: A facial pain disorder characterized by recurrent paroxysms of unilateral, electric shock-like pain in the trigeminal nerve distribution

scopeNote.@value: Covers diagnosis, classification into classic and secondary types, and treatment from carbamazepine to surgical decompression

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic presentation of trigeminal neuralgia
Distinguish classic from secondary TN based on red flags
Order appropriate imaging with neurovascular sequences
clinical_pearls: Electric shock pain triggered by light touch to face = pathognomonic for TN
Normal neuro exam in classic TN; abnormal exam = think secondary cause
Carbamazepine response is so characteristic it's considered 'therapeutic diagnosis'
Check HLA-B*1502 in Asian patients before carbamazepine (SJS risk)
Bilateral TN or age <40 = MRI to rule out MS or tumor
common_misconceptions: TN is continuous pain - no, it's paroxysmal with pain-free intervals
All facial pain is dental - TN is triggered by touch, not by tooth pathology
Surgery is always risky - MVD has 80-90% cure rate with low morbidity
